title: Riot, it's about time you normalized ranges of spells and autoattacks to be on one standard
body:
This is a ridiculous archaic mechanic that doesn't even make sense. 

Here's what I mean. Autoattack and spell ranges are NOT measured using the same standard. Autoattack ranges are measured from the end of the target champion's model, whereas spell ranges are measured from the center of the champion's model. 

I.e. The range a caster would be able to cast from a 6 stack cho'gath would not be different from a 0 stack cho'gath, because the center of Cho's model doesn't change; HOWEVER, the range an autoattacker would be able to attack a 6 stack cho'gath would be much farther than a 0 stack cho'gath because the end of his model increases in length. Basically, a 700 range spell is MUCH shorter than a 700 range autoattack, etc. 

There's really no reason autoattack and spell ranges aren't measured using the same standard. You guys went on about "clarity" being a priority when changing summoners rift; making AAs and spells use the same standard would be much better because many players don't know about this difference in standards and would help clarify that no, Jax leap does NOT have more range than caitlyn AA.

The logic might be that autoattacks (bullets) should be calculated from the impact range, which makes sense, but then what's the difference between a bullet and ryze's Q? If cho'gath increases in size I'm pretty sure it'd make more sense for Jax to leap as soon as he gets in range of his tail instead of saying "Hm, his center isn't in range but he has a good 6 feet of tail that I can jump to... Nah I'll wait."

Edit: Fyi this refers mainly for targetted spells like Nasus W, Jax Q, Ryze Kit (lol) etc. Pretty sure skillshots are measured using edge to edge too

You took it in the exact opposite way of what the OP was saying lol.

He isn't speaking of model size increases increasing the range of the larger model's spells/basic attacks, but rather the the standard sized  adc/mage's effective range when *attacking* the model size increased champion.

To put in simpler terms:

Marksman with 600 range hits target from slightly further than 600 due to basic attacks targeting the model's hitbox and not the center of the model.

Mage with 600 range spell hits target at exactly 600 range due to spells targeting the center of the model and not the model itself.

So if the model size increases the marksman can now shoot it from even further away while spells still have to be exactly 600 units from the model's center regardless of its size.

Comprende?

If everyone's ranges worked on the same standard, increasing your size wouldn't help you at all, since everyone else would also have increased range against you. I completely agree with this. Edge-to-edge range measurement should be the standard for all remaining targeted spells, as it syncs directly with the visual feedback you'd get from a champion and their hitbox.

Generally, there are a few under-the-hood spell mechanics out there that just need to be standardized: a little while back, Riot was focusing on making ults with cast times reset their cooldowns if the user died before completing the cast (e.g. {{champion:222}} launching her Super Mega Death Rocket! or {{champion:99}} casting her laser and them dying before firing either), and more recently there were a few adjustments to targeted spells by making them edge-to-edge. League probably needs an overhaul to its underlying systems (Rioters keep complaining about how a lot of its tech and code is old and clunky), and in doing so should unify mechanics like these.

It makes sense really. Most autoattack (not all) are physical attacks being made with the end of a limb. Even the magic based autoattacks such as {{champion:161}} come from the end of a limb. But most abilities (again, not all) come from either inner power or some mechanism near the center of a champ. 
Since you brought it up, let's use the 6 stacks {{champion:31}} example. His autoattack gains range as his arms grow longer, as longer limbs naturally grant longer reach. But none of his abilities are generated by his arms. His Q is generated by magic, and comes when he stomps his feet (which are located near the center). His W comes from his mouth, which again is located much closer to the center then his arms. His E is being launched from his body, which is of course his center. And finally his R is once again his mouth, which is near the center of his model. So as you can see, it is perfectly logical to have autoattack range cone from the end of the model, and ability range to come from the center.

For the sake of clarity, this change needs to occur. You can't PUSH for clarity like Riot has done, but keep something simply for "thematic" representation if it is unclear... that's pretty counter-intuitive.

I disagree with your opinion here. 

I think there should be pros and cons to autos versus spells.  I think right now there are both in a balanced way,  whereas this change would remove this. 

Right now,  having a larger champion hitbox makes you more easily hit by auto attacks and by skillshot spells,  but targeted spells gain no advantage.  Similarly,  a smaller hitbox makes you harder to hit with skillshots and forces closer range for auto attacks,  but targeted spells aren't at a disadvantage.  

So targeted spells are relatively better against smaller hitboxes, and skillshots (/autos) are more effective against larger hitboxes.  If you make targeted spells edge to edge,  it's just one more disadvantage for larger hitboxes.  Larger champions have enough disadvantages,  mainly wrt skillshots,  already.  Further,  it just doesn't make sense for a targeted spell to be edge to edge,  in most cases a targeted spell hits its target dead on the center to cause the desired effect,  if you allowed edge to edge it wouldn't be the same and should have reduced effects when you hit the edge. In contrast,  making a skillshot need to hit the center is equally ridiculous,  it would make no sense to watch an ahri charm fly right through cho'gath but not charm him (or any other skillshot). From a flow gameplay you need skillshots to be able to hit champions anywhere. 

Auto attacks are more flexible,  but in general a larger champion should benefit from increased attack range.  A fully stacked cho'gath should be able to reach farther than an empty one.  An adc hit with a lulu ult should be able to shoot their weapon farther than one without it. 

Not to mention,  it's not at all like spell/attack ranges aren't balanced for this difference... Riot is well aware of it and has even made patches to update ranges to accurately reflect these differences.  The amount of rebalancing required alone is enough to make this not worth pursuing,  even if the logic arguments above didn't apply.
I think this is to make up for the fact that cho is easier to hit with stacks than a no stack cho.
And even if doing this doesn't work, they could make spell ranges scale with size like basic attacks.
